qas.question: Instead of genetic traits for production, dogs are bred for what?
How many "fixed" genes demonstrate the differences between the wolf and dog?
The gene differences indicate what two things done by selection in dogs during breeding for domestication?
What is the common trait selected for dogs in overall breeding?
What do most dogs show less of than wolves?
Most domestic animals were selected for what traits?
For wolves and dogs, how many fixed genes show a variation?
Dogs show less fear and what as opposed to wolves?

context: Unlike other domestic species which were primarily selected for <a5_0>production-related traits<a5_0/>, dogs were initially selected <a6_0>for their <a0_0>behaviors.<a6_0/><a0_0/> In 2016, a study found that there were only <a1_0><a7_0>11<a7_0/><a1_0/> fixed genes that showed variation between wolves and dogs. These gene variations were unlikely to have been the result of natural evolution, and indicate selection on both <a2_0>morphology and behavior<a2_0/> during dog domestication. These genes have been shown to have an impact on the catecholamine synthesis pathway, with the majority of the genes affecting the fight-or-flight response (i.e. selection for <a3_0>tameness<a3_0/>), and emotional processing. Dogs generally show reduced <a4_0>fear and <a8_0>aggression<a8_0/><a4_0/> compared to wolves. Some of these genes have been associated with aggression in some dog breeds, indicating their importance in both the initial domestication and then later in breed formation.
